newsitem.title: FRANCE: FEATURE - Oracle says goodbye PC, hello network computer.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Oracle says goodbye PC, hello network computer.

text.p: Is the world at the brink of a new computing age? Are the days of the personal computer numbered, even before it has invaded every home? Will Bill Gates's dream of a personal computer on every desk never be realised?
According to Lawrence "Larry" Ellison the answer is yes.
Ellison, founder and chairman of Oracle Corp, believes that the future lies in a small, simple and cheap computing box -- the network computer.
It will be as small as a set-top box on a television, simple because it does not have a hard disk or lots of complicated software, and cheap because it will be free for almost everybody.
"A year ago I said it would cost as little as $500. I was wrong," Ellison told the Oracle Developers Conference in Paris this month.

"The only people who will pay are people who want to plug it into their own network. But I believe that phone companies and Internet access providers will make them available for free in exchange for a monthly subscription fee," said Ellison.
He anticipates a fee of about $20 a month with unlimited access to the Internet.
BATTLE OF THE TITANS
Ellison, a billionaire yachtsman who dreams of acquiring a MiG29 Russian fighter plane, is the network computer prophet.
He travels the world to extoll the virtues of what he believes will become the mass appliance that will really push the globe into the information age.

Cheap networking, with a set-top box you can plug into your television and which gives you electronic mail, Internet access and some productivity tools such as word processors and spreadsheet, are Ellison's holy grail.
His devil is Bill Gates and the Wintel monopoly of Microsoft software running on Intel powered personal computers.
"Is the Microsoft PC the last computer to have been invented?" asked Ellison.

His theory states that the computer industry has 15-year life cycles of which the mainframe, the personal computer and the network computer are stages, with that of the network computer starting this year.

Like Microsoft, Oracle is a sofware company. Microsoft is the world's biggest and Oracle comes second but has the lead in business applications. Gates's personal wealth is estimated at $18 billion; Ellison's "only" six.
Oracle specialises in applications for running networks and network servers -- the elements that would allow a network computer to operate.
A personal computer has a lot of autonomy with storage capacity and sofware applications. They can be linked to networks but they are generally over-equipped for average use, and rather expensive.
LITTLE BLACK BOX
The network computer is a little black box. Ellison demonstrated a prototype with a 200 Mhz Strongarm chip as well as one with an Intel 166 Mhz chip which should be commercially available shortly.
All the applications and data for the network computer are on the server, accessible over the Net -- Internet or private intranet -- at whatever location.
Ellison demonstrated smartcards with user identification which he expected people to have to tap into public network computers in hotels, airports or other places.
"This year, 50 to 60 million PCs will be sold. With network computers the numbers will be a multiple of that," he said.

During the demonstration, he surfed the Internet, viewed pictures and video images with cinema quality and played music that sounded a good as from a hi-fi system -- all directly from the server, with nothing downloaded onto the computer.
The only hitch is that the network computer, just like a PC, gets slowed down by jams on the Internet.
But to Ellison that is a passing problem. "The telephone companies will take control of the Internet backbone, they will make the necessary investments so that it runs well," he said.
The actual machines, or rather family of machines, are not made by Oracle and Ellison has no intention of changing that.
Apple Computer Inc, WebTV and Thomson SA's RCA unit are working on network computers for the home while IBM and Sun are working for the business market.
For the business market, a network computer would need more frills such as a network printer.
POWER TO THE NETWORK
Ellison hopes the network computer will take over from the personal computer, just as personal computers took over from the big central mainframes.
The user remains, however, in charge of the data and applications stored under the user profile on the network.

Microsoft, meanwhile, is developing both a NetPC -- a cheaper terminal-like desktop computer that takes its data and applications from a network -- as well as the Window CE operating system which will support small applications such as personal assistants.
Bernard Vergnes, chairman of Microsoft in Europe, says the big theme for business clients would be the "cost of ownership" instead of just the price of a new computer.
This means that computers should be able to stay around for many years while software too should be easily upgradable.
For Microsoft, the answer is a netPC and Windows NT.
At IBM, where the personal computer was born, executives are embracing the network, but not necessarely the network computer.
Lucio Stanca, chairman of IBM Europe, said that "intelligence" would go to the network.

"First we had big systems with large machines and dumb terminals. Then came the (smaller, smarter) personal computer. Now companies are becoming network centered," Stanca said, adding big computers are needed to run a network.

Whether Oracle or Microsoft will win the battle for dominance in the home will depend on the market and whether consumers want a cheap machine controlled by an anonymous system, or want to pay more to get computing autonomy.
Whatever the outcome, Ellison, who founded Oracle in 1977, expects the network computer to have a "substantial impact" on sales -- of Oracle network application software -- and results from 1998.
Oracle made a pre-tax profit of $919.5 million in the year to May 1996 on sales of $4.22 billion. "We think that in the year 2000 the NC will outsell the PC," Ellison said.
